text: I think part of it is also just saying, "We don't have to be hesitant to jump into these problems. It's important to engage with experts in the field, is not to say that tech solutionism is always the answer." And again, this is not super sophisticated technology, but because we were able to go in and talk to the people who are actually affected, get into the system that already existed, and make something really simple, really fast, it actually did have a huge difference and that's really exciting.
speaker: Zoelle Egner
context: Lenny asks Zoelle what she learned from building VaccinateCA, a volunteer organization that helped people find COVID vaccine locations during the pandemic. VaccinateCA was created when vaccine availability was extremely chaotic, with different eligibility rules at every location. Zoelle explains that they built a simple system using phones, Discord, and Airtable to help hundreds of volunteers call vaccine locations and create a comprehensive database. She's sharing lessons about how tech can solve important problems without being overly complex.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 한 부분은 '이런 문제들에 망설이지 않고 뛰어들어도 된다'고 말하는 것도 포함되는 것 같아요. 해당 분야 전문가들과 적극적으로 교류하는 게 중요한데, 그렇다고 해서 기술적 해결주의(tech solutionism)가 항상 정답이라는 뜻은 아니에요. 그리고 다시 말하지만, 우리가 쓴 기술이 엄청 복잡한 건 아니었어요. 대신 실제로 영향을 받는 사람들과 직접 만나고, 이미 존재하던 시스템 안에 들어가서 정말 단순하고 빠르게 뭔가를 만들어 보니까 큰 차이가 났고, 그게 정말 흥미로웠어요.
text_zh: 我觉得很重要的一点就是，我们不用害怕去解决这些问题。当然了，要跟行业专家多交流，但这不是说技术万能论(tech solutionism)就一定对。还有啊，我们用的技术其实也不算多复杂，但关键是我们真的深入进去，跟受影响的人聊，了解现有的体系，然后做出了一个特别简单、特别快的解决方案，结果真的产生了巨大的影响，这让人挺兴奋的。
text_es: Creo que parte de esto también es simplemente decir: "No tenemos que dudar en meternos de lleno a resolver estos problemas. Es importante trabajar con los expertos del sector, pero eso no significa que la tecnología siempre sea la solución mágica." Y otra vez, no estamos hablando de tecnología súper sofisticada, pero como pudimos entrar y hablar directamente con la gente que realmente se ve afectada, meternos en el sistema que ya existía, y crear algo realmente sencillo y rápido, al final sí tuvo un impacto enorme y eso es súper emocionante.

text: I think if you have an authentic mission and people aren't just like, "Oh, sure, okay. You're connecting the world." But really it's some telephony startup. Like, "Okay." If people feel like it's genuinely authentic to what you're building, it can be incredibly meaningful.
speaker: Zoelle Egner
context: Lenny and Zoelle are discussing how having a compelling mission makes it much easier for startups to hire talent. Zoelle had just explained how VaccinateCA attracted hundreds of volunteers because the mission was so clear and meaningful. They're talking about the difference between companies with genuine, impactful missions versus those with generic or manufactured mission statements that don't truly reflect what the company does.
text_ko: 제 생각엔 미션이 진짜라면 사람들이 '아, 그래. 세상을 연결한다는 거구나' 하고 겉으로만 수긍하는 수준이 아니어야 해요. 반대로 실은 텔레포니 스타트업(telephony startup) 같은 거라면 사람들도 '음, 알겠어' 하고 그냥 넘어가죠. 사람들이 그 미션이 당신이 실제로 만들고 있는 것과 진심으로 맞닿아 있다고 느끼면, 그건 엄청 의미가 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得如果你有一个真正的使命感，而不是让人觉得"哦好吧，你们说是要连接世界"，但实际上就是个电话技术的创业公司，这样的话人们会想"得了吧"。如果大家觉得你做的事情确实跟你在构建的东西是一致的、是发自内心的，那这个意义就太大了。
text_es: Creo que si tienes una misión auténtica y la gente no dice simplemente "Ah, sí, claro. Estás conectando el mundo" cuando en realidad es solo una startup de telefonía. Como que "Bueno, está bien." Si la gente siente que realmente es genuino lo que estás construyendo, puede ser increíblemente significativo.

text: I think I repeated the same three talking points about why what we were doing mattered 5,000 times. Cannot overemphasize how many times I said the same stuff, and so did every other member of the board. It really is important and people will fill in the blanks with totally wild things if you don't continuously have that discipline of repeating yourself.
speaker: Zoelle Egner
context: Lenny asks Zoelle about the second lesson she learned from running VaccinateCA. Zoelle is explaining the critical importance of constantly repeating key messages when managing a large, diverse group of volunteers. VaccinateCA had hundreds of volunteers from different backgrounds joining and leaving at different times, making clear communication essential. She's emphasizing how leaders must be willing to repeat the same core messages thousands of times to keep everyone aligned.
vocabulary_highlights: fill in the blanks with totally wild things
text_ko: 우리가 하는 일이 왜 중요한지에 대한 같은 세 가지 토킹 포인트(talking points)를 5,000번은 반복한 것 같아요. 제가 같은 얘기를 몇 번이나 했는지 아무리 강조해도 지나치지 않아요. 이사회(board)의 다른 구성원들도 모두 똑같이 반복했어요. 이건 정말 중요한데, 계속해서 반복하는 규율(discipline of repeating yourself)이 없으면 사람들은 빈칸을 완전히 엉뚱한 내용으로 채워 넣더라고요.
text_zh: 我觉得我把为什么我们做的事情很重要这三个要点重复了5000遍。真的不夸张，我说了无数遍同样的话，董事会其他成员也是这样。这真的很关键，如果你不坚持不断地重复，人们就会自己脑补出各种离谱的东西来填空。
text_es: Creo que repetí los mismos tres puntos clave sobre por qué lo que estábamos haciendo era importante como 5,000 veces. No puedo exagerar lo mucho que dije las mismas cosas, y todos los demás miembros de la junta también. De verdad es súper importante y la gente se inventa cosas completamente locas si no tienes esa disciplina de repetirte constantemente.

text: So if you can be like, "Here are three templates that a person you might be excited about." That can be really helpful. Where people sometimes get confused about templates, or have the wrong expectations about templates, is when they think that templates are going to be an acquisition mechanism, and they don't build in the foundation that is necessary for that to be true.
speaker: Zoelle Egner
context: Lenny asks Zoelle about her thoughts on the power and importance of templates for software companies, noting that many companies now create templates because they see how successful they were for Airtable and Notion. Zoelle is explaining that templates can be valuable for helping horizontal products (those that can be used for many different purposes) narrow down the use cases for users, but many companies misunderstand their primary purpose and expect them to drive new customer acquisition.
vocabulary_highlights: that is necessary for that to be true
text_ko: 그래서 '여기 흥미로워하실 만한 템플릿(templates) 세 가지가 있어요'라고 보여줄 수 있으면 정말 도움이 돼요. 사람들이 템플릿에 대해 혼동하거나 잘못된 기대를 가지는 건, 템플릿을 사용자 획득 수단(acquisition mechanism)이라고 생각하면서 그게 효과를 내려면 필요한 기반을 마련하지 않기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 所以你可以这样说："这里有三个模板，可能是你会感兴趣的那种人用的。" 这样会很有帮助。但是大家有时候对模板(template)会有误解，或者期望值不对，就是觉得模板本身就能帮你获客，但其实他们没有先把必要的基础打好，这样肯定不行的。
text_es: Entonces si puedes decir algo como: "Mira, aquí tienes tres plantillas de gente que te podría interesar." Eso puede ser súper útil. Donde la gente a veces se confunde con las plantillas, o tiene expectativas equivocadas sobre ellas, es cuando piensan que las plantillas van a ser un mecanismo de captación (acquisition mechanism), pero no construyen la base que se necesita para que eso realmente funcione.

text: What it is good for is credibility. And that's where, if you have really clear goals, and you know how you are ready to leverage the asset of a piece of PR coverage, then it can be helpful to you. So the two goals I always recommend to founders when thinking about using PR, are either hiring or maybe improving the response rate for your cold outbound.
speaker: Zoelle Egner
context: Lenny asks Zoelle about her potentially "spicy" take on launches and PR for early-stage startups. Zoelle has just explained that PR is generally not effective for getting leads or users directly, since most people won't click through from articles or remember to search for the company later. She's now explaining what PR is actually useful for and providing specific, measurable ways startups can leverage PR coverage effectively.
text_ko: 그게 좋은 점은 신뢰도를 쌓아준다는 거예요. 바로 그럴 때, 목표가 정말 명확하고 PR 보도(PR coverage)를 어떻게 활용할지 준비가 돼 있다면 도움이 될 수 있어요. 그래서 제가 창업자들에게 PR을 활용할 때 항상 추천하는 두 가지 목표는 채용(hiring)이나 콜드 아웃바운드(cold outbound)의 응답률(response rate)을 높이는 것이에요.
text_zh: 它的好处主要是能提升可信度。所以如果你的目标很明确，知道怎么利用好一次PR报道带来的价值，那确实会很有帮助。我一般建议创始人做PR的时候，主要考虑两个目标：要么是为了招人，要么是为了提高冷邮件(cold outbound)的回复率。
text_es: Lo que sí te sirve un montón es para credibilidad. Y ahí es donde, si tienes objetivos súper claros y sabes cómo vas a aprovechar el activo de una cobertura de PR, entonces sí te puede servir. Así que los dos objetivos que siempre les recomiendo a los fundadores cuando piensan en usar PR, son o para contratar gente o tal vez para mejorar la tasa de respuesta de tu outreach en frío.

text: Minimally. I'll say, if you care about this, send me a message. I will give you some advice. All of our industry will be better if there are more people working on customer success. So I will help you. Send me a note. Otherwise, I'll try and dig out some other things and maybe you can share them, but there's not a ton.
speaker: Zoelle Egner
context: Lenny asks Zoelle for resources that founders can use to learn how to invest in customer success early, since she had just recommended that B2B companies hire customer success before sales (which Airtable did). Zoelle explains that while there are many resources for customer success professionals, there aren't enough resources specifically aimed at helping founders understand how to set up and utilize customer success teams effectively.
text_ko: 간단히 말하면, 이 일에 관심 있으시면 저에게 메시지 주세요. 조언해 드릴게요. 고객 성공(customer success) 분야에 더 많은 사람이 참여하면 우리 업계 전체가 더 좋아질 거예요. 그래서 도와드릴게요. 연락 주세요. 아니면 제가 다른 자료들도 좀 찾아볼게요. 그걸 공유해주실 수도 있고요, 다만 많지는 않아요.
text_zh: 很简单。我就这么说吧，如果你真的在意这个事儿，给我发个消息。我会给你一些建议。如果有更多人做客户成功(customer success)这块，咱们整个行业都会更好。所以我会帮你的。给我留个言。要不然的话，我试着再挖掘一些其他的东西，也许你可以分享一下，但说实话也没那么多料。
text_es: Mínimamente. Te voy a decir algo: si esto te interesa de verdad, mándame un mensaje. Te puedo dar algunos consejos. Toda nuestra industria va a mejorar si hay más gente trabajando en éxito del cliente (customer success). Así que te voy a ayudar. Escríbeme. Si no, voy a tratar de buscar algunas otras cosas y a lo mejor las puedes compartir, pero no hay mucho que digamos.
